tn.text: The writer shifts into listing several merisms of life.

tn.ref: For everything there is an appointed time, and a season for every purpose
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: born and ... die ... kill and ... heal
tn.text: These are various aspects of life as described from one extreme to the other. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])

tn.ref: a time to pull up plants
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "a time to harvest" or 2) "a time to weed" or 3) "a time to uproot."
The writer continues with merisms of life.

tn.ref: weep and ... laugh ... mourn and ... dance
tn.text: These are various aspects of life as described from one extreme to the other. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
The writer continues with merisms of life.
The writer concludes his merisms of life.

tn.ref: What profit does the worker gain in his labor?
tn.text: This is a thought provoking question to focus the reader on the next discussion topic.
Here the word "their" refers to human beings. AT: "placed eternity in the hearts of human beings"
the writer is emphasizing the practice of enjoying one's work, not an intellectual knowledge of how to go about enjoying one's work.
See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ecc:01:09|1:10]].

tn.ref: I have seen the wickedness ... wickedness was there
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing and emphasize how common wicked behavior is. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
AT: "people often find wickedness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
AT: "I said to myself" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
These two phrases mean basically the same thing and refer to every action that people do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: There is no advantage for mankind over the animals
tn.text: AT: "Mankind is no better off than the animals"

tn.ref: is not everything just a breath?
tn.text: AT: "Everything is just a breath" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Who knows whether the spirit ... into the earth?
tn.text: The writer is making a claim that animals do have a spirit. AT: "No one knows whether the spirit ... into the earth." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: there is nothing better for anyone than to
tn.text: See how you translated this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:ecc:03:12|3:12]].
No one has raised any person or animal from the dead. AT: "No one can bring ... after him." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
